articles.headline: She Left France to Fight in Syria. Now She Wants to Return. But Can She?
articles.snippet: The case of a woman in France who became a prominent propagandist for the Islamic State is unusual, but points to a broader quandary for Europe.
articles.abstract: The case of a woman in France who became a prominent propagandist for the Islamic State is unusual, but points to a broader quandary for Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Having spent the last five years living in Syria, where she joined Islamic extremists, Emilie König, 33, wants to come home to France. But does France want her back?

articles.headline: What’s $27 Billion to Wall Street? An Alarming Drop in Revenue
articles.snippet: Investment banks used to mint money from trading bonds, currencies and the like. But that business is in decline, a trend that is reshaping Wall Street.
articles.abstract: Investment banks used to mint money from trading bonds, currencies and the like. But that business is in decline, a trend that is reshaping Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twenty-seven billion dollars has gone missing on Wall Street.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter and Kate Kelly

articles.headline: Dropbox Is Said to Be Planning to Go Public This Year
articles.snippet: The online storage company, one of Silicon Valley’s closely watched “unicorns,” has filed confidentially to stage an initial public offering.
articles.abstract: The online storage company, one of Silicon Valley’s closely watched “unicorns,” has filed confidentially to stage an initial public offering.
articles.lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley has birthed many highly valued and hugely hyped start-ups in recent years, including Uber, Airbnb and Pinterest. Few of those companies have made it out onto the stock market successfully.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Electric Vehicle Tax Credit Survives, but G.M. and Tesla Aren’t Cheering
articles.snippet: The manufacturers complain that they will soon be at a disadvantage — once they hit a sales mark that leaves their buyers without the benefit of a tax credit.
articles.abstract: The manufacturers complain that they will soon be at a disadvantage — once they hit a sales mark that leaves their buyers without the benefit of a tax credit.
articles.lead_paragraph: House Speaker Paul D. Ryan called electric vehicle tax credits “money wasted on losers.” The head of the Environmental Protection Agency, Scott Pruitt, said he’d “do away” with renewable energy subsidies.

articles.headline: Trump Alarms Lawmakers With Disparaging Words for Haiti and Africa
articles.snippet: President Trump demanded to know at a White House meeting why he should accept immigrants from Haiti and African countries rather than people from places like Norway.
articles.abstract: President Trump demanded to know at a White House meeting why he should accept immigrants from Haiti and African countries rather than people from places like Norway.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Thursday balked at an immigration deal that would include protections for people from Haiti and some nations in Africa, demanding to know at a White House meeting why he should accept immigrants from “shithole countries” rather than from places like Norway, according to people with direct knowledge of the conversation.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis, Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: Facebook Overhauls News Feed to Focus on What Friends and Family Share
articles.snippet: In the next few weeks, you will see fewer viral videos and news articles from media companies, and instead see more posts that include interactions between you and the people you know.
articles.abstract: In the next few weeks, you will see fewer viral videos and news articles from media companies, and instead see more posts that include interactions between you and the people you know.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook has introduced sweeping changes to the kinds of posts, videos and photos that its more than two billion members will see most often, saying on Thursday that it would prioritize what their friends and family share and comment on while de-emphasizing content from publishers and brands.

articles.headline: Victims of California Mudslides Were Swept Away Weeks After Surviving Fires
articles.snippet: The mudslides in Montecito, Calif., wiped out entire blocks, pulling people from their homes and killing at least 18.
articles.abstract: The mudslides in Montecito, Calif., wiped out entire blocks, pulling people from their homes and killing at least 18.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For more than two weeks last month, Josie Gower shuffled between her friends’ spare bedrooms and couches while her own home in Montecito, Calif., was under evacuation orders because of the devastating Thomas Fire. So on Monday evening, she told her adult children she was grateful to sleep safely in her own two-story home.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Medina and Patricia Mazzei

articles.headline: The End of the Social News Era? Journalists Brace for Facebook’s Big Change
articles.snippet: Media executives watch skeptically as Mark Zuckerberg, in a heated political environment, shifts the focus of his site back to the personal.
articles.abstract: Media executives watch skeptically as Mark Zuckerberg, in a heated political environment, shifts the focus of his site back to the personal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, said in an interview with The New York Times on Thursday that he wanted the social network to focus on “meaningful interaction.” But his idea of what that phrase means is likely to differ from that of news industry executives and editors — and therein lies a conflict.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: A Senior Republican Senator Admonishes Trump: ‘America Is an Idea, Not a Race’
articles.snippet: The president’s racially charged comments threaten an emerging agreement to project some undocumented immigrants, which risks bringing a government shutdown.
articles.abstract: The president’s racially charged comments threaten an emerging agreement to project some undocumented immigrants, which risks bringing a government shutdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was just after President Trump had finished railing in the Oval Office against African immigrants he said came from “shithole countries” when a senior Republican senator, Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, who was there to negotiate a deal on immigration, spoke up.
